text:
I know what it's like; it's late at
night, you're staring in front of the

computer, you're thinking: "Ah, I should
be doing something useful, but I'm kind

of tired. I don't really have the energy
to do anything useful". So, I'll have a

look at that, and I have a look at that.
And then when I'm really tired: "Oh. I'm

just too tired; I can't do the thing I
want to do." My name is Benjamin. And in

this video, I'm going to be looking at
study habits, routines, and mindset to

make sure that the time you have for
improving your English is well spent.

You see, for me, I know that I'm most
productive when I've got a good routine.

So, my first thing that I have to do...
I'm not saying everyone has to have

horses; I haven't had horses all my
life. And the... I don't... these don't

even belong to me. But what I'm saying
is: It's good to have something outside

and physical, like to go outside first
thing in the morning. So, my... my

morning routine: I come out; I come up
here, and, you know... then I have to

clear out their stable, take them
outside because these... these two,

there — they're my responsibility. So...
right. Come on, Zeus; come on, Bailey —
let's go out. We come. Out they go.

You see, if I — first thing — try to sit
down in front of the computer and start

studying, my brain would be, like, a
little fuzzy; it wouldn't be thinking

very straight. I'm someone... I need the
fresh air. I need... It just, like,

clears my head off for a night of sleep.
And it's good to get some oxygen into

the lungs, oxygen up to the brain, so
that when I am ready to work, I go back

down and I can think straight, and you
know... I'm focused. Okay? And I know

that I've got these two — they're taken
care of. Yeah? I can relax — that is

done. Okay? So, let's get them out the
stables, and then I can clear it out.

Brett, what are you up to? There you go.
Go on. So, by doing physical work, it

helps us with a sense of... of
well-being. Okay? Now, I know a lot of

people live in the city, and getting
outside, you know... you can sort of go

and run around a park; like, go to an
outdoor gym or something, but if... if

we're feeling good in our bodies, then
our mind is more able to focus on what
it is doing.

Now, the next thing I want to talk about
is sense of challenge and comfort zone.

So, I'm not really a horsey person, as
you can probably tell; but recently, a

friend of ours who has just given birth
— she's had a baby — she was running a

riding stable; a place for horses, where
children went to have... have riding

lessons. And because she was having the
baby, she couldn't look after these two

ponies, here. So, she came to my wife
and I, and said, you know... "Know you

two have got children, and you like your
boy riding. Do you think you could look

after them?" And we could have been
like: "No way." You know? "We've got

enough going on in our lives — we don't
need that change". We've got a dog,

we've got a cat, we've got, you know...
two kids, running a business — like, all

sorts of things going on. But it was
like: "Yeah, okay. Let's do this.

Challenge accepted." And when we take on
challenges, that's when we grow. When we

do things that are, like, slightly
outside of our comfort zones — that's,

like, the zone of growth. So, if you'd
asked me, like two months ago, if I

thought I could walk two ponies around a
wood on my own whilst carrying a baby on

my back — no, probably not. But by
having to do things, you just do them.

So, I think there's a danger in life of
too much planning; too much thought.

"Oh, I'm only going to do that when I'm
absolutely ready." But if you have to do

things, because there's, like, no choice
— then you're learning as you go along.

So, how does that relate to, like,
English-language learning? Well, if you

go and live in an English-speaking
country, then you're hearing English the

whole time and you're having to
communicate in English for your... your

day-to-day life, and perhaps your work.
I went to go and live in Spain, and I

didn't really know any Spanish; I had to
learn Spanish. So, think of ways in

which you... instead of, like, you
know... being part of a Facebook group

or watching something passively — like,
how can you actually apply what you

know? How can you put it to the test?
Because that is where you will grow.

So, I'm going to tell you a quick story
now, which is about how to respond to

life when life is a bit difficult. So,
there was once an old farmer, and he had

this donkey that was very, very old. And
it was costing him a lot of money to

keep the donkey alive. He kept on having
to go to the vet. And the vet, you know

what the vet's like — they can be very
expensive. So, he decided he didn't...

he didn't want to shoot the animal, so
what he did, you see, he got it... he

made it go down a well. You know?
Circular structure with water down at

the bottom. Okay? I don't know how he
got it down there, but, you know...

donkey down in the well. But this
donkey, being a donkey that wouldn't

give up — he got down at the bottom,
there. It was like: "Oh, here I am. It's

not very nice, but, you know... it'll be
okay". And one day they... well, some

people in the village, they were
throwing stuff down into the well. I

think they were... they were, like,
trying to bury the donkey or something.

And the donkey saw their stuff coming
down. It was like: "Oh, what's this?" He

stepped to the side. And stuff came down
there. And he saw more stuff, and he

stepped to the side. Gradually, he
worked out that he was going up, and up,

and up, and up until he got to the top
and he was able to hop out again. And

yes, he was old; yes, he had a couple of
pains in his joints — but he survived.

And the moral of that story is that, you
know... if life has been difficult, and

we have problems — you got to try and
step on top of them. Because that

process of building, and growing, and
adapting is what keeps us going; it
keeps us alive.

So, one of my jobs is making sure
they've got fresh water to drink when

they're out here. There we are. Now,
it's quite, you know... in life, we can

be... we can get all sort of wrapped up
in ourselves, and can be like: "I've got

to do this, I've got to do this, I've
got to do this", and you can kind of

forget about other people. But if you...
if you give and if you kind of care for

others, like, you know... I'm just
looking after these horses now, but it

gives me a warm, fuzzy glow inside
because they're kind of my

responsibility; I'm looking after them.
And if we're thinking about, like,

optimal mindset and, like, being in a
really good zone so that we can learn,

and improve, and progress — if we do
spend a bit of time, like, each day or

each week, looking after others, whether
that is visiting an elderly relative or,

like, washing some plates in a homeless
shelter or, you know... looking after

some animals in a sort of rescue centre;
walking someone's dog. It doesn't take

us... take long, but it can energize us
to then go back and attack our work
with, like, renewed energy.

Now, the next thing I want to talk about
is more of a lifestyle thing. So, a few

months ago, I was... I was teaching in a
very good school, but wasn't

particularly enjoying it. And I... I
decided to get out of there and set up

my own business. And I think we can get
trapped in these situations for so long

that you're not, like, really growing
in; you're not really, like, fulfilled

by — and you're kind of scared to break
through and to break out with that,

like, structure that is supporting you.
And it can take quite a lot of courage

to quit something. You know... you're
worried about what people are going to

think, but... I'm not saying: Be
reckless. I'm saying, like: You got to

think about decisions. But, for me:
Getting out of something I didn't want

to be in and starting to concentrate on
running my own business — it's allowed

me to, you know... I wouldn't be able to
be looking after these horses if I was

commuting two hours a day and working
six days a week, and working really long

hours. So, sometimes when you let go of
stuff that you don't really like, the

new things can start flowing into your
life.

I appreciate that this video has been a
little bit different. We're used to

Benjamin standing in front of a
whiteboard. What on Earth is going on?

But, look, let's just review what we
said. If we want to be... come here. If

you want to be productive, if you want
to make sure that the time spent

learning, spent in front of a computer
is time well spent — then, let's get

outside; let's get physical. And
remember, you know... when we help

others, we actually help ourselves;
helps our sort of mental state. Naughty,

naughty, naughty. Hey. So, that's it for
me today, but thank you very much for

watching. And until next time, get out
there. Let's get busy. Let's get active.

Let's get physical. Please remember to
subscribe. If you want more help with

your English, I help high-end
professionals to write and speak better.

Visit www.honeyourenglish.com. Thanks,
guys. And ring that bell.
